/home/mgh/LanlGeoMag/libLanlGeoMag/Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /* TraceToSphericalEarth, Copyright (c) 2010 Michael G. Henderson <mghenderson@lanl.gov>
00002  *
00003  *    - Attempts to trace FL down to (some height above) the Earth.
00004  *
00005  *     This is a version of Lgm_TraceToEarth, but in this version the Earth is
00006  *     approximated by a sphere of radius WGS84_A (i.e. the equatorial radius
00007  *     in the WGS84 model). This is useful for computing magnetic flux of a
00008  *     drift shell since a spherical surface is much easier to compute B dot dA
00009  *     on. The magnetic flux doesnt care what surface we use, so using a
00010  *     spherical earth for that isnt an approximation...
00011  *
00012  *
00013  * Permission to use, copy, modify, distribute, and sell this software and its
00014  * documentation for any purpose is hereby granted without fee, provided that
00015  * the above copyright notice appear in all copies and that both that
00016  * copyright notice and this permission notice appear in supporting
00017  * documentation.  No representations are made about the suitability of this
00018  * software for any purpose.  It is provided "as is" without express or
00019  * implied warranty.
00020  *
00021  */
00022 
00023 #include <stdio.h>
00024 #include <stdlib.h>
00025 #include "Lgm/Lgm_MagModelInfo.h"
00026 #include "Lgm/Lgm_WGS84.h"
00027 
00028 
00029 
00030 
00031 
00032 int Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth( Lgm_Vector *u, Lgm_Vector *v, double TargetHeight, double sgn, double tol, Lgm_MagModelInfo *Info ) {
00033 
00034     Lgm_Vector  u_scale;
00035     double      Htry, Htry_max, Hdid, Hnext, Hmin, Hmax, s;
00036     double      Sa=0.0, Sc=0.0, d;
00037     double      Rinitial, Fa, Fb, Fc, F;
00038     double      Height, StartHeight;
00039     double      Height_a, Height_b, Height_c, HeightPlus, HeightMinus, direction;
00040     Lgm_Vector  Pa, Pc, P;
00041     int         done, reset, AboveTargetHeight;
00042 
00043 
00044     /*
00045      * Determine our initial geocentric radius in km. (u is assumed to be in
00046      * units of Re where we define Re to be WGS84_A.)
00047      */
00048     Rinitial = WGS84_A*Lgm_Magnitude( u ); // km
00049 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: Rinitial = %g km\n", Rinitial);
00050 
00051 
00052     /*
00053      * The Earth is a spheroid. It is more flattened at the poles than at the
00054      * equator.  Check to see if we are initially at a height where we need to
00055      * worry about it. For WGS84 Earth shape model, the equatorial radius is
00056      * WGS84_A and polar radius is WGS84_B (WGS84_B is about 20km smaller than
00057      * WGS84_A).
00058      *
00059      * Note that although we are trying to trace to a spherical Earth in this
00060      * routine, we still dont want to drop below the surface of the real Earth
00061      * (IGRF doesnt like that so much).
00062      *
00063      */
00064     if ( Rinitial < WGS84_B ) {
00065 
00066         // must be inside the Earth, which is no good -- bail with
00067         // LGM_INSIDE_EARTH error code
00068         return( LGM_INSIDE_EARTH );
00069 
00070     } else {
00071 
00072         // We are at least at or above WGS84_B. We could still be in trouble in
00073         // terms of being inside the Earth, so we have to check more
00074         // thouroughly now.  Determine Geodetic Height
00075         Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( u, &Height );
00076 
00077         if ( Height < 0.0 )  {
00078 
00079             // inside the Earth, which is no good -- bail with error
00080             return( LGM_INSIDE_EARTH );
00081 
00082         }
00083 
00084     }
00085 
00086 
00087     /*
00088      *  If we get here, the initial point must be above the surface of the
00089      *  (spheroidal) Earth.
00090      *
00091      *  Now check to see if we are currently above or below the target height.
00092      *  (reset Height to be distance in km above the spherical approx of the Earth.)
00093      */
00094     Height = Rinitial - WGS84_A; // distance above spherical Earth
00095     AboveTargetHeight = ( Height > TargetHeight ) ? TRUE : FALSE;
00096 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: Height, TargetHeight = %g, %g km\n", Height, TargetHeight);
00097 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: AboveTargetHeight = %d\n", AboveTargetHeight );
00098 
00099 
00100 
00101     /*
00102      * Initialize some things
00103      */
00104     Pa.x = Pa.y = Pa.z = 0.0;
00105     Pc.x = Pc.y = Pc.z = 0.0;
00106     P = *u;
00107     Hmax = Info->Hmax;
00108     Hmin = 0.001;
00109     Hmin = 1e-8;
00110     u_scale.x =  100.0;  u_scale.y = 100.0; u_scale.z = 100.0;
00111     Height = Height_a = Height_b = Height_c = 0.0;
00112     F = Fa = Fb = Fc = 0.0;
00113 
00114 
00115 
00116     /*
00117      * Save initial point if we need to 
00118      */
00119     if (Info->SavePoints) fprintf(Info->fp, "%f \t%f\t %f\t 3\n", u->x, u->y, u->z);
00120 
00121 
00122 
00123     /*
00124      * If we are above the target height, a potential problem will occur if the
00125      * field line is open in the direction of tracing.  Fortunately, that
00126      * situation is easy to detect and is taken care of later...
00127      *
00128      * Here we need to test for and deal with the opposite problem. If we are
00129      * already below the target height, it is possible that the field line
00130      * never gets high enough to reach the target height. This is more tricky
00131      * to deal with because we can run the risk of getting below the surface of
00132      * the Earth.  We need to try to get back above the target height to test
00133      * for this.  If we cannot get above we need to bail out of the routine
00134      * altogether.
00135      */
00136     StartHeight = Height;
00137     if ( !AboveTargetHeight ){
00138 
00139 
00140         /*
00141          *  Determine which direction along the field line will take us higher.
00142          */
00143         Htry = 0.001;
00144 
00145         // sgn = +1
00146         P = *u; Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, 1.0, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00147         HeightPlus = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00148 
00149         // sgn = -1
00150         P = *u; Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, -1.0, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00151         HeightMinus = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00152 
00153         direction = ( HeightPlus > HeightMinus ) ? 1.0 : -1.0;
00154 
00155 
00156 
00157         /* 
00158          *  We are already at or below target height. Trace until we are not.
00159          */
00160         done  = FALSE;
00161         reset = TRUE;
00162         while ( !done ) {
00163             Htry = fabs(0.9*(TargetHeight - Height));       // This computes Htry as 90% of the distance to the TargetHeight
00164             if (Htry > 0.1) Htry = 0.1; // If its bigger than 0.1 reset it to 0.1 -- to be safe.
00165             Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, direction, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00166             Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00167             F = Height - TargetHeight;
00168             if ( F > 0.0 ){
00169                 done = TRUE;
00170             } else if ( Height < StartHeight ) {
00171                 // We are going back down again -- Target Height unreachable? -- Bail out
00172                 return( LGM_TARGET_HEIGHT_UNREACHABLE );
00173             }
00174         }
00175 
00176     }
00177   
00178 
00179 
00180 
00181 
00182 
00183 
00184 
00185     /*
00186      *  Bracket the zero first. 
00187      *  We want to stop in the ionosphere at a certain height above the Earth
00188      *  (assumed to be a spehere of radius WGS84_A in this routine).  We need
00189      *  to find 2 points along the field line such that the intersection of the
00190      *  FL with the sphere is guaranteed to lie between them. To do this, we
00191      *  need to find two points; Pa and Pc such that;
00192      *  
00193      *      and  Height( Pa ) - TargetHeight   >   0.0
00194      *      and  Height( Pc ) - TargetHeight   <   0.0
00195      *
00196      *  I.e., F = Height - TargetHeight has opposite signs
00197      * 
00198      *  Set the start point, Pa and Fa. (Fa is difference between Height_a and
00199      *  TargetHeight.)
00200      *
00201      */
00202     Pa   = P;
00203     Height_a = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &Pa )-1.0);
00204     Sa   = 0.0;
00205 
00206 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: Pa = <%g, %g, %g> Re\n", Pa.x, Pa.y, Pa.z );
00207 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: Height_a = %g\n", Height_a );
00208 
00209     /*
00210      *  Get an initial Htry that is safe -- i.e. start off slowly
00211      *  We dont really know where we are, so be conservative on the first try.
00212      *  If Lgm_MagStep() gives back an Hnext thats higher, we'll crank Htry up then...
00213      */
00214     Htry = 0.9*Height_a;        // This computes Htry as 90% of the distance to the Earth's surface (could be small if we are already close!)
00215     if (Htry > 0.1) Htry = 0.1; // If its bigger than 0.1 reset it to 0.1 -- to be safe.
00216     
00217 
00218 
00219     /*
00220      *  Keep stepping along the field line until we drop below the target
00221      *  height, TargetHeight.  (Or bail if its open). This completes the endpoints of the
00222      *  bracket pair. We get these points first, because there are field lines
00223      *  that have more than one local minimum in fabs(Height-TargetHeight). So find Pa and Pc
00224      *  first and then complete the triple later. CHECK on this. I changed this
00225      *  from a minima search to a simple root finder. Is it OK still?
00226      */
00227     P     = Pa;
00228     done  = FALSE;
00229     reset = TRUE;
00230     while ( !done ) {
00231 
00232         Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, sgn, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00233         Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00234         F =  Height - TargetHeight;
00235         if ((F > 0.0) && (Info->SavePoints)) fprintf(Info->fp, "%f \t%f\t %f\t 2\n", P.x, P.y, P.z);
00236 
00237             if (   (P.x > Info->OpenLimit_xMax) || (P.x < Info->OpenLimit_xMin) || (P.y > Info->OpenLimit_yMax) || (P.y < Info->OpenLimit_yMin)
00238                 || (P.z > Info->OpenLimit_zMax) || (P.z < Info->OpenLimit_zMin) ) {
00239             /*
00240              *  Open FL!
00241              */
00242             v->x = v->y = v->z = 0.0;
00243             return(0);
00244         } else if ( F < 0.0 ) {
00245             done = TRUE;
00246             Pc = P;
00247             Height_c = Height;
00248             Fc = F;
00249             Sc += Hdid;
00250         } else {
00251             Pa = P;
00252             Fa = F;
00253             Height_a = Height;
00254             Sa = 0.0;
00255         }
00256 
00257         Htry = Hnext; // adaptively reset Htry
00258 
00259         /*
00260          *  Go no farther than some small distance below 
00261          *  the target Height. Also respect Hmin and Hmax.
00262          */
00263         Htry_max = 0.9*Height;
00264         if (Htry > Htry_max)  Htry = Htry_max;
00265         if      (Htry < Hmin) Htry = Hmin;
00266         else if (Htry > Hmax) Htry = Hmax;
00267 
00268 
00269     }
00270 
00271 
00272 
00273 
00274     /*
00275      *  We have a bracket. Now go in for the kill.
00276      *
00277      *  (Note: If all we wanted to know is whether or not the line hits the
00278      *  TargetHeight, we could stop here: it must or we wouldnt have a minimum
00279      *  bracketed.)
00280      *
00281      *  Use golden-section search to converge toward minimum.
00282      *  (Sa, Sb, Sc) are the distances of the triple points along
00283      *  the FL. For convenience, we maintain Sa = 0.0, so that
00284      *  Sb and Sc are always the distances relative to Pa. (And
00285      *  so Sc is always the width of the bracketed interval. So when
00286      *  Sc gets small enough we bail out and take Pb as the min).
00287      *
00288      */
00289     done  = FALSE;
00290     reset = TRUE;
00291 Sa = 0.0;
00292 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: About to go in for kill \n");
00293 //    Htry = LGM_1M_1O_GOLD*(Sc - Sa);
00294     while (!done) {
00295 
00296         d = Sc - Sa;
00297     
00298         //if ( fabs(F) < tol ) {
00299         if ( fabs(d) < tol ) {
00300             done = TRUE;
00301         } else {
00302 
00303             P = Pa; //Htry = LGM_1M_1O_GOLD*d; // LGM_1M_1O_GOLD is 0.381966...
00304 //            if ( Htry > 2.0*fabs(F) ) {
00305                 //Htry = LGM_1M_1O_GOLD*d; // LGM_1M_1O_GOLD is 0.381966...
00306                 Htry = 0.5*fabs(d); // LGM_1M_1O_GOLD is 0.381966...
00307 //            }
00308             Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, tol, sgn, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00309             Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00310             F =  Height - TargetHeight;
00311 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: Inside kill loop. Htry, Hdid, Hnext, tol, F = %g %g %g %g %g      P = %g %g %g\n", Htry, Hdid, Hnext, tol, F, P.x, P.y, P.z);
00312 //printf("Pa, Pc = %.15lf %.15lf\n", Lgm_Magnitude(&Pa), Lgm_Magnitude(&Pc) );
00313             if ( F >= 0.0 ) {
00314                 Pa = P; Fa = F; Sa += Hdid;
00315             } else {
00316                 Pc = P; Fc = F; Sc = Sa + Hdid;
00317             }
00318 
00319         }
00320     }
00321 
00322 
00323 
00324     /*
00325      *  Take average as the final answer.
00326      */
00327     v->x = 0.5*(Pa.x + Pc.x); v->y = 0.5*(Pa.y + Pc.y); v->z = 0.5*(Pa.z + Pc.z);
00328 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToSphericalEarth: v = %g %g %g\n", v->x, v->y, v->z);
00329     if (Info->SavePoints) fprintf(Info->fp, "%f \t%f\t %f\t 2\n", v->x, v->y, v->z);
00330 
00331     return( 1 );
00332 
00333 }
00334 
00335 /*
00336  *   $id$
00337  */
